text: As a cell grows in size, the surface area gets bigger, but the volume gets bigger faster. Thinking about this as a ratio (division), the volume is the denominator and the surface area is the numerator. If the volume is getting very big, then the ratio itself will be getting very small. What this translates to is as a cell gets larger, with a larger volume, it has a smaller SA:V. A smaller SA:V means that diffusion of nutrients and diffusion of waste in less efficient (harder to do). The rate of diffusion doesn't change, but it would take longer for the nutrients to diffuse through to the centre of the cell than a cell with a higher SA:V (a smaller cell - i.e. a cell with a smaller volume)
question: What does surface area have to do with how much energy it takes for these transfers to occur?

text: The entropy of a macro-system is proportional to the number of micro-states the system can be in that are compatible with the macro-state of the system. To make this notion precise, one has to specify the definition of macro-states and micro-states and how the micro-states will be counted. Sal is not providing those details here, but is speaking more qualitatively. Still, the entropy increase with either volume increase or temperature increase can be understood at this qualitative level. The micro-state of a gas is given by the location and velocity of each molecule in the gas. If the volume increases, the molecules have more locations they can be at, hence more micro-states. If the temperature increases, the molecules have more velocities with which they can move, hence more micro-states. Remember that absolute temperature is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the molecules, so increasing temperature increases the range of velocities the molecules are likely to have. This is an increase in the number of micro-states.
question: How come an increase in temperature increases this combination of states?

text: We determine the oxidation state by an agreed upon set of rules. It is just a record keeping system. It is very, very helpful, which is why we use it, but it is still just a group of rules. There are a great many chemicals that for which the oxidation state rules tell use a great deal, but there are also some chemicals where the oxidation state rules don't really help much at all. Here are the rules: (0) Oxidation states can only be integers. (1) the oxidation state of a free element (uncombined element) is 0. There are no exceptions. (2) for a simple (monatomic) ion, the oxidation state is equal to the net charge on the ion. (3) Except in its elemental state, fluorine always has −1. There are no exceptions. (4) Except in its elemental sate, hydrogen has +1, except in hydrides of active metals, e.g. LiH, where it as an oxidation state of −1 (5) Oxygen has a state of −2 except in peroxides and superoxides where it has a state of −1 or when combined with fluorine in which case it has whatever state is needed not to contradict the rule that fluorine must be −1 (usually oxygen will be +2 with fluorine). (6) the algebraic sum of oxidation states of all atoms in a neutral molecule must be zero, while in ions the algebraic sum of the oxidation states of the constituent atoms must be equal to the charge on the ion. (7) Group 1 elements, except in the elemental state, have +1 (8) Group 2 elements, except in the elemental state, have +2 (9) Chlorine, bromine, and iodine, except in the elemental state, have −1 states except where that contradicts the rules for oxygen and fluorine. In compounds containing only chlorine, bromine and/or iodine (e.g. BrCl) then the lower atomic number element will have −1 and the higher atomic number element will have whatever is necessary not to contradict other rules (usually +1).
question: How to determine the oxidation state of oxygen?

text: An atom may donate an electron and attain octet configuration or it may gain electron and attain octet configuration. It is also possible that the atom shares its electron(as in O2) and attain stability. The bond formed by donating or gaining electron is called ionic bond. The bond formed by sharing of electrons is called covalent bond Hope that helped. There are three types of bond. The nonpolar covalent bond is when the electrons are equally shared between the two atoms and don't have a preference. Then there is the polar covalent bond like in water, where the electrons are still shared between the two atoms but shows a preference to the more electronegative atom (oxygen), because oxygen simply has a stronger tendency to attract electrons than the hydrogen does. Finally, there is an ionic bond where the difference in electronegativity is so great that it is no longer sharing electrons. In the case of an ionic bond, chlorine steals an electron (or sodium loses an electron) because of the tendency to fill its valence shell to its full configuration for both atoms. All three bonds are equally possible for stability between the two atoms, but the ionic bond is the special bond that involves a complete transfer of electrons.
question: Do the atoms share the electrons (and therefore form a bond)?

text: 1.Duplicated chromosomes are identical to each other, more accurately we call them *sister chromatids*and two sister chromatids together is one chromosome. However, homologous chromosomes are two chromosomes with different versions of genes. One homologous pair contain two chromosomes. 2. For example, if you are a male, then your sex chromosome would be XY so during interphase your X chromosome and Y chromosome would be doubled. So when the somatic cell goes in to the mitosis stage, the X and Y sister chromatids would be separated, resulting in each one X and Y chromosome again in each daughter cell. That's why your cells in your body all have XY chromosomes. In meiosis, crossing over also happens at sex chromosomes but the region where the crossing over would happen is limited and it is called pseudoautosomal region. But overall the crossing over would not harm the function of sex chromosomes. One thing meiosis is different from mitosis is that if you are a male, your four haploid daughter cells would have two each contain one X chromosome and the other two each contain one Y chromosome, meaning none of your gamete has a complete pair of sex determine chromosome like XX or XY.

text: photon frequency are exact. The precision must be extremely high - within the bounds of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. You might as well just say it has to be exact. If there's not a precise match, the photon will not be absorbed. The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle says that the energy levels are not exact unless the uncertainty in the time (lifetime of the excited state) is infinite. Of greater practical importance are two factors which give rise to non-zero line widths (the widths at half-height of the line profiles): (1) the Doppler effect, since atoms moving toward you will appear to emit light of slightly higher frequencies (a blue shift) whereas atoms moving away from you will appear to emit light of slightly lower frequencies (a red shift), and this effect becomes more pronounced at higher temperatures, since the average speeds of the molecules becomes greater, and (2) pressure broadening, since atoms or molecules colliding with each other have electrons with motions perturbed from their state in isolated atoms or molecules.

text: Voltage and current sources generate both voltage and current. The difference between them lies in which parameter (voltage or current) is being controlled. A constant voltage source (like a battery) is designed to generate a controlled voltage. When you put a constant voltage source in a circuit, the voltage across its terminals is always a constant value. Depending on what it is connected to, a voltage source provides (generates) whatever current is needed to keep the voltage on its terminals constant. Example: a 1.5 V battery connected to a 100 ohm resistor will generate a current of 1.5/100 = 15 mA. If you change the resistor to 10 ohms, the voltage will still be 1.5 V but the voltage source will now generate a current of 1.5/10 = 150 mA. Current sources may seem a little strange, but they behave exactly like a voltage source, but with current being controlled. A constant current source is designed to generate a controlled current. When you put a current source in a circuit, the current through the source is always a constant value. Depending on what it is connected to, a current source provides whatever voltage is needed to keep the current on its terminals constant. Example: suppose you have a constant current source set to current = 1 mA. If you connect a 100 ohm resistor across the current source, the voltage will be V = 1 mA x 100 ohms = 0.1 V. If you change the resistor to 1000 ohms, the current will still be 1 mA and the voltage generated by the current source will rise to V = 1 mA x 1000 ohms = 1 V. Most transistors (MOSFET, Bipolar) and the old vacuum tubes have a region of operation where they act just like a current source.
question: Don't a voltage source and a current source both supply a current and voltage in a circuit?

text: Certain Plants do grow better around each other and help each other out. Researcher Dr. David Johnson looked closely at plants' symbiotic relationship with soil fungus, piggybacking off a 2010 study that seemed to suggest that a tomato plant infected with leaf blight would be able to warn nearby plants of the problem. In turn, those plants would activate genes that would prevent them from catching the disease, too. Johnson was able to show how plants use fungus in the soil as a network (think of it as a botanical Wi-Fi, if you will). Essentially, fungi deliver messages of danger from plant to plant, and as a result, the group can grow stronger. text: Hydrogen bonds and London dispersion forces are both examples of van der Waals forces, a general term for intermolecular interactions that do not involve covalent bonds or ions. In a water molecule, the bond connecting the oxygen to each hydrogen is a polar bond. In a polar covalent bond containing hydrogen (e.g., an O-H bond in a water molecule). The hydrogen-oxygen bond in water is not a hydrogen bond, but only a polar covalent bond. However, after hydrogen and oxygen have formed a water molecule and hydrogen has become partially positive, then the hydrogen atoms become attracted to nearby negative charges and are 'available' for hydrogen bonding. The hydrogen bond between these hydrogen atoms and the nearby negatively charged atoms is weak and doesn't involve the covalent bond between hydrogen and oxygen. Thus, hydrogen bonding is a van der Waals force.
question: How does the hydrogen bond in it conform to their definition of van dear Waals forces, which don't involve covalent bonds?

text: Think of voltage as elevation on a mountain. Suppose people take a hike starting at some elevation (typically the bottom of the mountain where elevation = 0). As people hike up, their elevation (voltage) increases. When people reach a high point and walk down, their elevation (voltage) decreases. People walk all day, up and down and all around the mountainside. At the end of their hike them return to their starting point. If people come back to their starting point, all the ups and downs their total change of elevation is 0. That is the essence of Kirchhoff's Voltage Law.
question: Why do the voltages have to add to zero when we end up back at the same voltage?

text: The ability to transform base metals into Gold was one of the main goals of Alchemists in in Middle Ages and Renaissance Europe, and it was called Chrysopoeia. However, the final goal of the Alchemist was not the making of money. It's even been done in nuclear reactors. Sadly, there are two problems: 1) You normally get a radioactive form of gold (a radio-isotope), so it doesn't stay gold for very long. 2) The cost to make the gold (cost for the electricity you need to power a particle accelerator or whatever) is bigger than the price of gold. Transmutation of atoms or changing of one atom to another is possible but involves high costs. You will have to shell out a lot of bucks to transmutate 1 gram of lead to 1 gram of gold but the money you earn from selling the gold, will be insignificant compared the cost of converting lead to gold. We can change atoms into gold or any other element,however the expense of adding or removing nucleons ( protons & neutrons ) would in itself be so much ,so I don't think you could get rich by doing it, plus ,the technology is way too expensive.But maybe it'll be easier in the future. Technically speaking, it could be possible through atomic fusion, but stars, the original source of fusion, only has enough energy to create iron through this process. While a solar fusion engine has been created, it would need several times the power it can give to fuse elements heavier than iron. Also, the energy to run said engine would cost so much that it would be cheaper to try to extract minerals from asteroids in space.

text: Being able to get useful work from a system of energy requires you to go from a low entropy or more ordered form of energy to a higher entropy of less ordered form of energy. If you want to use heat as an energy source you need to have a lower temperature area for the heat energy to go to. If you have a steam engine you have to use fuel to add heat to the water to get it to a temperature where is converts to steam. This steam expands into the cooler environment. In this case you are taking the low entropy energy in the chemical bonds of the fuel and creating high entropy heat energy that transferred to the water increasing its entropy when it gets hotter and eventually converts into steam creating the pressure to do work like creating electricity. If the entire environment was as the same temperature of the burning fuel the water would already be steam and it couldn't be made to do anything.

text: The electron can only have specific states, nothing in between. By releasing a photon of a particular amount of energy, an electron can drop into one of the lower energy levels. If it happens to drop to an intermediate level, not n=1, the it is still in an excited state (albeit a lower excited state than it previously had). It will, if conditions allow, eventually drop back to n=1. So, it is not a matter of the electron not returning to n=1, it is just that it might do so in a number of steps instead of all at once. An electron in the n=1 state is stable because it cannot go any lower, being already at the lowest allowed energy state state, and can only go higher if energy is applied. So, it cannot cannot spontaneously move. That is the sense in which it is stable. In general, an electron at any energy level cannot spontaneously jump up since that would require an outside source of energy. But it can at any time spontaneously jump down to any lower energy level by ejecting a photon. Any level below it is just as likely as any other for it to jump to. But it is a one-way ratchet. It can only go down, and it soons finds itself back at the bottom.
question: Why would an electron fall back to any energy level other than the n=1, since there are no other electrons stopping it from falling there?

text: With the exception of the hydrogen and helium that were formed shortly after the Big Bang event, elements mainly form in the following ways: 1. Fusion in the core of a star. 2. Fusion during a supernovae. 3. Decay of a radioactive isotope. 4. Being changed from one type of atom to another by high energy nuclear reactions, such as having a neutron slam into the nucleus at an extremely high velocity. There are a few other ways, but they are not all that significant. Each isotope (more properly called a nuclide) has its own way(s) in which it is formed. There is not one set way they form. So, it is not possible to give you a general answer other than to say that the isotopes of an element form in one or more of the above ways, but each isotope of an element may or may not form in a similar way as other isotopes. Except as listed above, an atom that is not radioactive never changes its number of neutrons. So you do not usually have one isotope changing into another isotope of the same element. There are ways it can happen, but they are not the normal course of events.
question: Do  isotopes ever lose the extra neutron(s) or gain new ones?

text: Hydrogen does not follow the octet rule, so that is part of why H2 is stable. Note: H2 is stable, but it is quite reactive. The octet rule follows from the energetic favorability of having both the s and p subshells either completely empty or completely full. There is no p subshell in shell number 1, so that is part of why the lightest elements do not follow the octet rule (there are other reasons). There are many considerations as to what does or does not make an atom with a particular electron configuration reactive or nonreactive. So, while the octet rule is a convenient rule of thumb, the reality of chemistry is much, much more complicated. So, with chemistry, there are many competing factors that affect how elements behave, so you cannot just take a single rule and insist or suspect that every element must necessarily follow that rule. It doesn't work that way. You have to take all of the factors into consideration to predict how an element might behave. NOTE: The Pauli exclusion principle is one of the few laws that all of the elements always obey. But the octet rule is not always followed.
question: Why are the elements in group 2 not stable with 2 valence electrons?

text: Resonance decreases reactivity because it increases the stability of the molecule. The reason why resonance is decreasing the reactivity of the carboxylic acid is because moving the electrons causes the carbonyl carbon to become less partially positive (which makes the carboxylic acid more stable). When you stabilize the carboxylic acid by making the carbonyl carbon less positive, you are decreasing its ability to be an electrophile in a reaction (in other words, you are making the molecule less reactive due to the increase in stability from the resonance). Reactivity and stability are two opposing concepts. The more stable a molecule is, the less it wants to react. A decrease in stability results in an increase in reactivity and an increase in stability causes a decrease in reactivity. Think of it this way: a molecule always wants to be in it's most stable form. If it's not stable, it is going to want to react in order to stabilize itself. If it's already stable, it doesn't need to react.
question: How is resonance decreasing reactivity?
